kexp.analysis.atomdata module

class kexp.analysis.atomdata.analysis_tags(crop_type, absorption_analysis, unshuffle_xvars)[source]

Bases: object

class kexp.analysis.atomdata.atomdata(xvarnames, images, image_timestamps, params: ExptParams, camera_params: CameraParams, run_info: RunInfo, sort_idx, sort_N, expt_text, params_text, cooling_text, imaging_text, unshuffle_xvars=True, crop_type='', transpose_idx=[], avg_repeats=False)[source]

Bases: object

Use to store and do basic analysis on data for every experiment.

xvarnames should be provided as a string indicating the params attribute corresponding to the the independent variable(s). They should be provided in the order over which they were looped, with the outermost loop first.

Any attribute which does not start with ‘_’ will be saved to the dataset in _save_data().

This class also handles saving parameters from expt.params to the dataset.

avg_repeats(xvars_to_avg=[], reanalyze=True)[source]

Averages the images along the axes specified in xvars_to_avg. Uses absorption imaging analysis.

Parameters:

  • xvars_to_avg (list, optional) – A list of xvar indices to average.

  • reanalyze (bool, optional) – _description_. Defaults to True.

transpose_data(new_xvar_idx=[], reanalyze=True)[source]

Swaps xvar order, then reruns the analysis.

Parameters:

  • new_xvar_idx (list) – The list of indices specifying the new order of

  • xvars. (the original)

  • example (For)

  • xvars (new_var_idx can also be set to True in the case of one or two)

  • [0 (specifying)

  • 2

  • 1

  • means (3])

  • swapped (that the second and third xvar will be)

  • and (while the first)

  • unchanged. (fourth remain)

  • In (No list needs to be provided for the case of one or two xvars.)

  • xvar (the case of one)

  • nothing. (does)

  • xvars

compute_phase_space_density(num_tweezers=2, tweezer_waist=3.6e-06, trap_wavelength=1.064e-06, tweezer_final_frequency=455.0)[source]
kexp.analysis.standard_experiments.get_B(f_mf0_mf1_transition, F0=2.0, mF0=0.0, F1=1.0, mF1=1.0, min_B=0.0, max_B=600.0)[source]
kexp.analysis.standard_experiments.magnetometry_1d(ad, F0=2.0, mF0=0.0, F1=1.0, mF1=1.0, axis=0, plot_bool=True, find_field=True, detect_dips=False, average_multiple_peaks=False, param_of_interest='', transition_peak_idx=-1, min_B=0.0, max_B=600.0, peak_prominence=10)[source]

Analyzes the sum_od_x for each shot and produces an array of the max-min OD (“signal”) vs. the RF center frequency. Extracts the peak signal from each of these arrays, and finds the frequency where it occurs. Based on expected microwave frequency for the known transition (specified by user), looks up the magnitude of magnetic field.

Produces a plot of the magnetic field vs. the scanned variable.

Parameters:

  • ad (atomdata) – _description_

  • F0 (int, optional) – The F quantum number of the initial state. Defaults to 2.

  • mF0 (int, optional) – The mF quantum number of the inital state. Defaults to 0.

  • F1 (int, optional) – The F quantum number of the final state. Defaults to 2.

  • mF1 (int, optional) – The mF quantum number of the inital state. Defaults to 1.

  • axis (int, optional) – The axis of the sumod to use for the peak finding.

  • 0 (Defaults to)

  • plot_bool (bool, optional) – If True, plots the signal vs. frequency

  • True. (for each value of the scanned xvar. Defaults to)

  • detect_dips (bool, optional) – If True, inverts the signal to identify a

  • False. (loss signal. Defaults to)

  • param_of_interest (str, optional) – If specified, adds the key and value

  • title. (of the param with that key to the)

  • transition_peak_idx (int, optional) – state specified by the quantum numbers F0,

  • mF0

  • F1

  • list (mF1. Indexes as a)

  • highest (with the peaks from lowest to)

  • peak (frequency. Default is the last)

  • min_B (float, optional) – the minimum B value in Gauss to use for the

  • calculation

  • with (useful if the transition frequency is non-monatonic)

  • 0. (magnetic field. Defaults to)

  • max_B (float, optional) – the maximum B value in Gauss to use for the

  • calculation

  • with

  • 600. (magnetic field. Defaults to)

  • peak_prominence (float, optional) – Specifies how prominent a peak has to

  • counted. (be in order to be)

kexp.analysis.standard_experiments.magnetometry_2d(ad, F0=2.0, mF0=0.0, F1=1.0, mF1=1.0, axis=0, subplots_bool=True, detect_dips=False, average_multiple_peaks=False, transition_peak_idx=-1, peak_prominence=10, min_B=0.0, max_B=600.0, subplots_figsize=[])[source]

Analyzes the sum_od_x for each shot and produces an array of the max-min OD (“signal”) for each value of the scanned variable vs. the RF center frequency. Extracts the peak signal from each of these arrays, and finds the frequency where it occurs. Based on expected microwave frequency for the known transition (specified by user), looks up the magnitude of magnetic field. Produces a plot of the magnetic field vs. the scanned variable (the first xvar).

xvar0: scanned variable xvar1: rf frequency

Parameters:

  • ad (atomdata) – _description_

  • F0 (int, optional) – The F quantum number of the initial state. Defaults to 2.

  • mF0 (int, optional) – The mF quantum number of the inital state. Defaults to 0.

  • F1 (int, optional) – The F quantum number of the final state. Defaults to 2.

  • mF1 (int, optional) – The mF quantum number of the inital state. Defaults to 1.

  • axis (int, optional) – The axis of the sumod to use for the peak finding.

  • 0 (Defaults to)

  • subplots_bool (bool, optional) – If True, plots the signal vs. frequency

  • True. (for each value of the scanned xvar. Defaults to)

  • detect_dips (bool, optional) – If True, inverts the signal to identify a

  • False. (be sure that only one feature is visible. Defaults to)

  • average_multiple_peaks (bool, optional) – If True, averages multiple

  • -- (peaks detected to obtain the center frequency. Use at your own risk)

  • False.

  • transition_peak_idx (int, optional) – state specified by the quantum numbers F0,

  • mF0

  • F1

  • list (mF1. Indexes as a)

  • highest (with the peaks from lowest to)

  • peak (frequency. Default is the last)

  • min_B (float, optional) – the minimum B value in Gauss to use for the

  • calculation

  • with (useful if the transition frequency is non-monatonic)

  • 0. (magnetic field. Defaults to)

  • max_B (float, optional) – the maximum B value in Gauss to use for the

  • calculation

  • with

  • 600. (magnetic field. Defaults to)

  • peak_prominence (float, optional) – Specifies how prominent a peak has to

  • counted. (be in order to be)

kexp.analysis.standard_experiments.rabi_oscillation(ad, rf_frequency_hz, plot_bool=True, pi_time_at_peak=True, fit_guess_frequency=1000.0, fit_guess_phase=1.5707963267948966, fit_guess_amp=-1000.0, fit_guess_offset=-1000.0)[source]

Fits the signal (max-min sumOD) vs. pulse time to extract the rabi frequency and pi-pulse time, and produces a plot.

xvar: rf pulse time.

Parameters:

  • ad (atomdata)

  • rf_frequency_hz (float) – The RF drive frequency in Hz.

  • plot_bool (bool, optional) – If True, plots the data and fit. Defaults to True.

  • pi_time_at_peak (bool, optional) – If True, assumes the initial

  • the (population is zero and extracts the pi-pulse time as the location of)

  • False (first peak in the fitted oscillation. If)

  • minimum (identifies the)

  • True. (as the pi-pulse time. Defaults to)

Returns:

The pi pulse time in seconds.

Return type:

t_pi

kexp.analysis.standard_experiments.rabi_oscillation_2d(ad: atomdata, plot_bool=True, subplots_bool=True, pi_time_at_peak=True, detect_dips=False, xvar0format='1.5f', xvar0mult=1e-06, xvar0unit='MHz', subplots_figsize=[], plot_figsize=[], fit_guess_frequency=1000.0, fit_guess_phase=3.141592653589793, fit_guess_amp=-1000.0, fit_guess_offset=-1000.0, rabi_freq_threshold=500.0)[source]

Fits the signal (max-min sumOD) vs. pulse time to extract the rabi frequency and pi-pulse time, and produces a plot.

xvar0: rf frequency xvar1: pulse time

Parameters:

  • ad (atomdata)

  • plot_bool (bool, optional) – If True, plots the data and fit. Defaults to True.

  • subplots_bool (bool, optional) – If True, plots subplots for each set of

  • fits. (scans over pulse time at fixed RF frequency. Includes)

  • pi_time_at_peak (bool, optional) – If True, assumes the initial

  • the (population is zero and extracts the pi-pulse time as the location of)

  • False (first peak in the fitted oscillation. If)

  • minimum (identifies the)

  • True. (as the pi-pulse time. Defaults to)

  • xvar0format (str, optional) – Defaults to ‘1.2f’

  • xvar0mult (float, optional) – Defaults to 1.e-6 (to convert Hz to MHz)

  • xvar0unit (str, optional) – Defaults to ‘MHz’.

  • subplots_figsize (tuple, optional)

  • plot_figsize (tuple, optional)

  • fit_guess_frequency

:param : :param fit_guess_phase: :param : :param fit_guess_amp: :param : :param fit_guess_offset: :param : :param rabi_freq_threshold: The threshold below which a fit :type rabi_freq_threshold: float, optional :param resulting in this rabi frequency will be discarded.:

Returns:

The Rabi frequency in Hz. t_pi (np.array): The pi pulse times in seconds. rf_frequencies (np.array): The RF frequencies at which each Rabi frequency / pi pulse time was measured.

Return type:

rabi_frequencies_hz (np.array)

Module contents

class kexp.analysis.atomdata(xvarnames, images, image_timestamps, params: ExptParams, camera_params: CameraParams, run_info: RunInfo, sort_idx, sort_N, expt_text, params_text, cooling_text, imaging_text, unshuffle_xvars=True, crop_type='', transpose_idx=[], avg_repeats=False)[source]

Bases: object

Use to store and do basic analysis on data for every experiment.

xvarnames should be provided as a string indicating the params attribute corresponding to the the independent variable(s). They should be provided in the order over which they were looped, with the outermost loop first.

Any attribute which does not start with ‘_’ will be saved to the dataset in _save_data().

This class also handles saving parameters from expt.params to the dataset.
